BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north, northeast and east facing slopes above approximately 2200 m. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be avoided as far as possible at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2200 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
Along the border between Valais and France In some localities up to 20 cm of snow will fall on Monday above approximately 2000 m. Here the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. In the course of the day in some localities danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in these regions above approximately 2200 m.
Fresh wind slabs are in many cases extensive and to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Several mostly small natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate to strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind was lighter than expected over a wide area.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2100 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Several mostly small natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the moderate to strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind was lighter than expected over a wide area.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. The wind slabs have bonded generally well with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of northwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be well bonded below approximately 2000 m.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. These represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are unlikely to be released now.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The large surface-area wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. In particular on very steep slopes more mostly small avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions will foster a strengthening of the snowpack.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise and prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. Especially gullies and bowls are unfavourable. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. These are mostly rather small but can in some cases be released easily. The somewhat older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Distinct weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants in particular on steep shady slopes. This applies in particular in little used terrain, as well as in areas where the snow cover is rather shallow above the tree line. Avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and reach a dangerous size. Isolated whumpfing sounds can indicate the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1900 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution. On shady slopes a moderate danger of dry avalanches will persist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can in some places be released by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for a certain restraint. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach large size in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
In particular in the west a little new snow above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will become well bonded over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
